job_title: Student Success Coach in Dallas, TX
pros:
Nice people to work with
Flexibility with hours when working from home
cons:
Too many to list but top 3 are:
- they have a culture of "apologizing to the client". During trainings it was drilled into us to constantly apologize. Instead of apologizing Strayer, how about fixing the problem to begin with??
-Financial Aid department is out of touch with what SS coaches have to do. The stringent guidelines (make sure that 4 corners of the page are showing on a scan otherwise we wont accept it) need to be revamped! This goes back to point #1..apologizing for bad policies and follow up from the FA team
- did I mention the drilling on of apologizing to the client CONSTANTLY? The phone lines have queues of 50+. I have seen way too many times where the calls are on hold for over an hour and when that student gets on, you bet they are mad if you can't answer their question. Why can't you answer it? Because you are on hold yourself to talk to a department at the school or because there is so much conflicting information given to the student because there are way too many coaches involved in the account.
This place is a dynamic mess and while the few people I work with are decent, honest people...upper management needs to streamline operations to make the experience for students and staff at SU enjoyable (or at least comparable) to other institutions.

cons: This is a customer front facing job- this means that if Strayer screws up, you'll be talking to people all day about it that call in because they will throw you under the bus before any other department. pros: Compared to similar institutions, the pay and benefits are very good. I also had the opportunity to work with some great people at the campus level.
cons: Where to begin? First of all, don't be fooled- this is NOT a professional librarian position. As an LRC Manager, you will provide onsite tech support, proctor standardized tests, and serve as a glorified babysitter. I would say that less than 10% of the job involves actual library work. You will work long hours and strange shifts, and when there are tasks that need done that no one else on campus wants to do, they will usually fall to you. Because you do not actively make the company money, management will not value your work, nor will they support you by providing any opportunities for professional development. You will probably work with some very good professors, but as academic-minded individuals working at a for-profit "university," you will feel like square pegs trying to fit in round holes. First and foremost, Strayer University is a business that exists to make money for the shareholders, and they do a good job of not letting academics interfere with that goal. The actual work the LRC Manager does is so menial (and the entire proprietary college system is so frustrating) that I would have a hard time recommending this job to anyone.

Within my role, I was able to affect and enhance the college life of the students.  It was a very satisfying and rewarding experience.  I was able to perform my duties without little guidance or management -- so individuals who are experienced or are adept at adapting to their role will find this organization to be a good fit.
cons:

Tons of politics. Probably the worst I've ever seen - and its been 4 years since I've been there, and I still feel that way. Unless you are part of the good ol' boys club, there is not a single chance you will get a promotion. 
Toxic management. They all play games, and if you don't eat out of their hands you don't get admission into their club.
Management constantly threatened my job and made me feel like I was the worst employee ever. This was literally said to me in a performance review "everywhere else your two mistakes are nothing, but here, they are major and might cost you your job"  yep you read that right! I made TWO mistakes - the whole time I was there, and they admitted they would be no big deal at any other company, but at their precious school, it was practically life and death, cause they're so much more important than everyone else. 
I got held back from moving to a position I would have excelled at, because of a rumor... No one fact checks there. And rumors are constant.
Worked stupidly insane hours, could never make plans cause I never knew when I would be off work.

job_title: Student Account Representative in Charlotte, NC
pros: Benefits, Helping Students, free coffee,  free internet to handle family business being you are forced to work from 9-8
cons: Each day you're reminded by management & VPs you can be laid off. They lay you off not based upon tenor & best qualified they lay you off if you're not apart of the clique!  They make you work until midday & then lay you off! Graduation Assistance Fund is designed to not work! They say it will pay up to 25% of your degree. What they fail to state is you have to have more than 10 courses remaining and it can only be used in the end.So if a student has used up student loans & pell grants (you will at Strayer) and you have more than 10 courses remremaining you can't use the funds until you have 10 classes remaining.  Other than that you're left out in the cold.  VPs send emails from foreign countries while on vacation threatening staff to get enrollments by any means necessary!  With that being said you have to lay off because the any means necessary will cause you enroll students who don't have a snowball chance in hell to graduate let alone pay their bills.

review_title: Run, Don't Walk, Away from Strayer University
pros: The best part of Strayer was helping good students who wanted to work hard and succeed at school and life.  If I have to name a pro, it would be those few good students. Faculty mean well but are 99% adjuncts, powerless and clueless. Operations staff are mostly sweating through mandatory weekly, sometimes daily meetings to meet enrollment and retention fantasy goals. A bad campus culture is a trainwreck, and a good campus culture will be ruined by psychopathic regional managers and faraway, out of touch corporate people who are beating a 120 year old horse to death.
cons: Campus staff are dedicated in the short term, but no one can stay motivated and effective with the schizophrenic regional management, who have gotten significantly worse in the last 3 years. Strayer talks Jack Welch Management "principles" but practices the opposite.  Regional management, especially in academics, are frightening in their lack of basic competence and willingness to lie, gossip, devalue and derail their campus staff.  Google the concept of "relational aggression" which sums up Strayer regional management completely: Female, bullying, backstabbing, and undermining. If you suck up, you get used and abused.  If you stand up for yourself, your students, your campus... watch your back.  Since October 2013, Strayer has axed 20 campuses and 20% of the workforce, and it has become a nightmare.  Strayer enrollment (like its stock... check STRA) is dropping like a stone, and this is one dead cat that ain't gonna bounce.

review_title: A great heritage and education with a good management team
pros: Strayer has an excellent heritage and truly strive to offer a quality education whether through their Jack Welch Mgt. Institute or Strayer University brand.  Anyone representing Strayer can stand proud of the academic quality and student care offered to all students.  A focus on graduate success is a driver for Strayer and it shows.  The COO teaches two filters in making a decision; what is best for the student first and then university second.  These make it easy for anyone to consider when faced with a decision and keeps integrity front and center where it belongs.
cons: Manpower models, especially in newer markets, are too thin when attempting to operate a campus to serve students.  Too often a small campus can end up with a single person and if there's turnover in any position it restricts all employees ability to serve and gives a perception to students the school itself may be struggling, even though it is not.

review_title: Company rewarded loyalty with layoffs due to bad business direction.
job_title: Learning Resource Center Manager in Orlando, FL
pros: Co-workers are great friends, networking helps secure work force friends, and IT was a great experience.
cons: 7 years of loyalty was rewarded with forced layoffs due to executives making very poor business choices and forgetting we were a university. To many management changes and changes in direction causes the company to not only have no idea how to correct the sinking ship but knee jerk reactions made things worse. Focus on operations and enrollment while cutting academics from over 7 down to just 2 seriously hurt the school. Rather than focus on quality they want quantity and the number of students enrolled dropped anyways because they were enrolling the wrong students.

review_title: i need strayer upper management to resign
pros:
the idea of helping students succeed is what drives me. also there are a lot of amazing people who work here and a lot of free food.

strayer has the potential to be a great company.
cons: however, those awesome people don't include upper management (CEO, VPs and Directors).  they have absolutely no strategy (and if they do it's conflicting) or clear, unified vision. management has a level of laziness i've never witnessed in a company of this size and they lack an understanding how to get stuff done at the enterprise level. the problems they have to solve are straightforward but they always take the longest, most complicated path to addressing them—or not addressing them at all.

review_title: A truly Super-fantastic (A+) university with quality educational programs, & superb faculty & leadership at every level.
pros: The university's drive for excellence in every area makes it a hallmark in the adult Higher Education community. From my observation for over 5 years at multiple levels...words cannot describe the positive drive, passion & dedication Strayer University's leaders, faculty and staff demonstrated daily to ensure each of their students experience a quality education.
cons: The cost for its learners to attend Strayer University is the only downside that is worth mentioning. As we know, there is no such thing as a perfect system (or person)...if I did find the perfect system...I would run quickly from it because I know I would be the one to mess it up.

review_title: Sales job but great work environment. Flexible hours, great benefits and good pay. It is what you make of it.
pros: My Strayer co workers are like family to me. Genuinely caring people who look out for each other. Schedule flexibility and good pay for not having a college degree yet. Working at the campus, there is always food so you WILL gain weight if you do not have self control :)
cons: Management can be very very pushy. It is all about numbers and registrations. If you are bringing in business you are on their good graces but if not, do not expect to be acknowledged. This IS DEFINITELY a sales job...regardless of what is said to you during your interview or training. Upper management does not realize how things really go down at the campuses.

pros: They give you a discount for taking classes if you work here.
cons: Everything. The Business Office side and the Academic Office side are constantly at war with eachother. Business cares about SALES, which leads them to sign up ANYONE for class. Meanwhile, the Academic staff gets stuck with people only looking to get a school refund check. This leads to unhappy professors, scarce physical classes on campus due to low enrollment, etc. The upper management turn over is frequent and the lower level staff are working long hours and being paid low wages. They often mandate OT hours and then in the same breath say that you will not be paid for OT. I am surprised this company hasn't been shut down yet. They are unethical to students and staff. All they care about is making money.

pros: Great employees. You will meet some of the most kind hearted and wonderful individuals. The employees on lower levels make the job.
cons: The upper level managers and people who do not have to deal with the student as some of the most misinformed idealistic people you will ever meet. They did not reward hard-work or going the extra. The didn't believe in a work life balance. There was no growth period. While I realize that the industry itself is waning they didn't even try to cultivate you in the interim. Whatever position you were hired in, you pretty much stay in.

review_title: It could be a great company if they cared more about eduation then numbers
pros:
The benefits were good
Advancement opportunity if you are willing you give up your life and mind
cons:
Management was the so unprofessional!!! Senior management was even worse. They that intimidation was the best way to communicate. The constantly changed the policies and procedures. Management did not look at outside factors that effected numbers, they thought it was Admissions job to waive the magic wand. No sense of employee loyalty, they will demote you for no reason or just cause. 

It could have the potential to be great for adult learners but its not geared towards education....they just want the number!!!

pros: Were helping students reach their goals.
cons: I worked for a very unethical, unprofessional manager.  She was not what I thought Strayer would have as an employee.  I received my MBA in Human Resource Management from Strayer and to work for a school that teaches ethics is shocking to me the they would allow a person to represent them terribly.  She used profanity when talking to us. She also talked about sex with her boyfriend to us.  She even had another job, and would leave in the middle of the work day to go to her other full time job.  She lied about my work ethic and fired me.  I am disappointed in how Strayer's HR department handle it and never followed up with me.  They have left a bad taste in my mouth

job_title: Learning Resource Center Manager in Washington, DC
pros: Strayer University values the employee as a human being, and does everything in its power to enforce that.  While it is a for-profit business and tough decisions need to be made, from time to time, those decisions are made with the best possible interests of its people in mind.  Further, the promotion potential (for those that actually want it) is outstanding.  I cannot say enough about this, the most amazing place to work!
cons: The only "con" is that organizational change is handled a bit haphazardly, but is almost always worth it in the end and easy to get through with the team.

job_title: Military Admissions Officer in Manassas, VA
pros:
90% off tuition - great place to work if you are trying to get your degree and work full time. 

inbound leads
cons:
The campuses get really lonely, because staff teams are small (usually only a few people in the building at a time). Students prefer to complete enrollments remotely, so most of your time is spent on the phone or sending emails

Management is inconsistent and negative 

No commission - you are paid a base salary regardless of whether you hit your goals or not 

Little to no advancement opportunities  - if you read reviews from about a year ago, people mention a lot of upward mobility. In September of 2017, Strayer laid off a large percentage of low-mid level management positions, and combined the roles of the remaining leaders. As a result, there is currently little to no advancement opportunity for current employees.

pros:
Online training exposes employees with new technologies and opportunities to learn
Great students working adults who want to learn.
Interesting colleagues from various backgrounds.
Teaching online allows for great flexibility.
cons:
Education model is questionable. There are no checks of student performance, faculty are not supported in academic discipline. Hiring and teaching assignments are too rigid and did not offer faculty with opportunities to grow professionally. 
Pay rates are very low and staff are overworked. There is a gross lack of resources like books, journals and a decent library. 
High staff and management turnover. I worked with three academic deans and five campus managers in a year and a half. 
Students did not receive the resources, supports, and academic preparation for the work force. Classes are overpriced.

job_title: Full Time Professor in Herndon, VA
pros: If you have never taught online before this is a great place to start.  Blackboard is the platform and there is a lot of training and support for new professors.  The classes are pre-built with syllabus, rubric (grading matrix) and textbooks which makes it easier to learn the systems.
cons: There is so much emphasis on making "numbers" from enrolling to keeping students,  that principles of teaching and learning go out the window.  Professors will get thrown under the bus if a student complains when policies (like the late policy) are being enforced.  Videos are a regular (weekly) requirement, but the emphasis is on quantity, not quality, and I have had students complain that the video feedback is useless.

review_title: Most professors try to do a good job, but Corporate does not seem to share same interest in student academic success.
pros: Each class meets only one day per week.  Staff and other instructors were friendly and helpful.  The Dean is very honest, sincere. Interested in student success. There were some very good students.
cons: Most students are not prepared for college level work.  Corporate cut money for tutoring and staff.  The students tend to be ill-prepared and in need of help outside of class.  Of course most students don't avail themselves of tutoring, but it has to be available.  New instructor evaluation by students (SOP) carry too much weight.  Poor evaluations are given by students who expect to fail classes.

review_title: One person in a role of power will ruin an entire school!
pros: Good pay and benefits. Great team of fellow admissions officers.  Good corporate benefits and employee benefits in general.  Set schedule weekly, which is great for planning.  No work going home with you.
cons: One person in a role of power with JWMI is going to bring the whole school within Strayer down!  The leaders of JWMI talk the talk of Jack Welch and his principles but do not follow it at all.  DO NOT work there if you are looking for a place that will welcome ideas, value your experience, and NOT FEEL THREATENED because you too also have a brain.

review_title: Don't work as Houston Campus Coordinator
pros:
Pros are its busy at times 
there is down time
room for overtime
great holiday set up
cons:
Cons the Director at the Katy, NW, Stafford locations is awful
Terrible communication
They give minimal training but quick to reprimand
He gave out the wrong information to students
you are accountable even if you were trained wrong
director was rarely in office so he was hard to reach
students complained he gave is contact out but never answered
VERY STRESSFUL

pros: An exciting higher educational experience that allows you to meet new people and assist them in the process of furthering their education. The university itself, allows you to recruit freely and use your personality to do so.
cons: It would be more of an advantage to the company if there were more constant round table meeting with those who receive, recruit and interact with the students on a more consistent basis. By doing this, upper level management can a better pulse of what goes on, on the ground level.

job_title: Student Success Coach in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Pay is pretty high for the Salt Lake City area, made some pretty great friends during my time there.
cons: There is a horrible lack of work/life balance. The company confuses the occasional free food for "culture", and they never practice what you preach. It's hard to remain positive on the phones with students when your inbox is filled with emails from your manager and team mates talking poorly about other members of your team.

review_title: Asking a lot for little money
pros:
Flexible hours
Great location employees
Nice students 
Off on Sundays
cons:
Headquarters staff does not care for or about part-time employees. They cut hours, pay little, does not provide gifts to part-time employees that they do full-time (thanksgiving turkeys), no benefits (medical or educational). 

Constantly demanding you do more/whatever it takes to get students enrolled even if they don't want to continue their education. 

Leadership only cares about numbers, nothing else, not what is best for employees or students.

pros: Health benefits and decent pay
cons: Terrible work-life balance, politics, extreme gossip to the point that many have walked out of the job in tears. I myself was sexually harassed by upper management for 4 months. When I contacted the Corporate DC office to complain as that was the only person higher than my supervisor, I was told it would be investigated and it never was. When the harassment continued, I mouthed off to the supervisor who was harassing me and was then let go for being "unprofessional" - mind you I had spent the last 4 months silently undergoing the harassment while waiting for someone to investigate it. Definitely no open door policy here and if I had enough evidence, I'd be suing Strayer. Unfortunately, all the sexual harassment I underwent was verbal so there was not enough evidence for me to do so. Avoid working at this place at all costs.

job_title: Computer Lab Monitor in Smithfield, NC
pros: One of the best empolyees as a whole across the whole business. Your fellow empolyees are always kind and help each other out, and they make the workplace nice with a very friendly atmoshpere. I love wroking for Strayer U.
cons: Some of the new bosses did not seem to understand the system and if an empolyee makes the normal request, these new people have a misunderstand of how the job is done. Some of the new changes do not seem to be cohesive, and make doing the job a bit off balanced.

pros: I started working with Strayer in 2009 and it was brilliant.  It was difficult but they worked very hard to support you.  You had a lot of freedom with course design and content so the class was basically your own.  It was a very challenging and rewarding job.
cons: In the Summer of 2011, Strayer implemented a standardized system.  It took away all instructor input in and control of the class.  In essence, I became a glorified paper grader.  They also instituted a new performance evaluation process which largely rated instructor performance on issues outside of their control.  Hopefully they have worked through this painful transition and regained some of their instructor-friendly ways, but I didn't stay to find out.

review_title: Not a great place to work (MONEY DRIVEN)
pros: Strayer University is a wonderful university for employees to get a free education.  They accommodate you for you classes.
cons: Depending on which campus you are working at, it can be very hostile.  The company does not care about workplace balance but the bottom dollar period.  They are numbers driven and don't care about the employee.  PLEASE DO NOT GET SICK FOR ANYTHING OR EVEN HAVE A BABY!  You will be fired at the end of the year.  It's truly sad when everyone you know that took FMLA for anything was let go because they had an illness.  Not family friendly.

pros:
Employees were amazing, I've met some truly awesome people here. Benefits are great, healthcare is very cheap for the quality you receive. 

The professors here really care about the students; many Strayer graduates often go on to do amazing things with the education they received from Strayer. Good quality degrees for non-traditional students.

You really have a chance to change people's lives here. With the new scholarships and such for students, it's much more cost-friendly than all other for-profits out there, and is even cheaper than many state schools.

Company is open to letting people transfer between departments, when needed.
cons:
Constantly changing strategy means that nearly all jobs outside of admissions and student support are always on the line (to include academics--yep, for a university, not even the deans and professors are safe!) 

Toxic managers are allowed to perpetuate horrible management practices because THEIR leaders do not seem to care to keep them in line. Micromanagement is commonplace if numbers are not where they are supposed to be. Rather than provide the resources to get the job done correctly, the leadership here would rather point fingers than fess up to bad business practices.

Executive leadership is too afraid to make needed changes to benefit students--seem to be too concerned with "Disneyland principles" than actually making much needed business changes. The only changes that seem to occur are terrible for the front-line employees, but allow the "top" leaders to continue to collect their bonuses despite poor growth and student performance.

Marketing money is absolutely pissed away with little to no direct results for the campuses.

job_title: Onsite Program Manager in Franklin, TN
pros: I was able to make an impact on Students within the Verizon Wireless call center.  I recruited these students with in the center and help them use their tuition assistance to get higher education.
cons: I had to fight for my salary to be above $45,000 when I secure more than 80 students per semester at the minimum of 1620.00 per class. No bonus, over worked, and the highest raise per year was at 1.5%.  The cost of living in  Nashville grows each year currently at 4.5% or higher.

job_title: Faculty Adjunct in Coral Springs, FL
pros: Good employer; pays very well; positive environment, excellent facilities for adjunct faculty (large common room, well appointed, spacious, inviting)
cons: Students, as with other for-profit institutions I have been at, are often unmotivated, mentally indolent, resentful of too much "work"(!), intermittent in attendance, and utterly unaware of what it means to be a university student.  At my campus, they will bully professors for good grades or else complain to the admin staff or give poor evaluations to professors.  Still, this is *not* a distinctive feature of Strayer, rather it is sadly the de facto state of all for-profit universities, in my experience.

job_title: Financial Aid Specialist in Herndon, VA
pros:
-Clean work environment.
-Semi-nice co workers.
-Not bad hours.
-Good training.
-Work is so easy a monkey could do it.
cons:
-Management is horrendous. 
-The people who work there do not care about the students and constantly verbally degrade them as soon as they get off the phone. And they never assist the student (delete fax and emails without uploading them causing students to send documents in several times.).
-On the phone "helping" students for 6 hours a day.
-NO ROOM TO GROW. If you take this job start looking for a new job ASAP because they have a high employee turnover as their employees are not worth anything to them.

review_title: Does not care about the students
job_title: Student Account Representative in Springfield, PA
pros: Good benefits; good work/life balance depending on your management team.
cons: The salary was too low and there weren't any opportunities for advancement. You had to be in the "clique" in order to get promoted. Management doesn't care about the students. Management only interested in enrolling new students but doesn't go above and beyond to retain current students.

pros: I started teaching English Fundamentals, and advance to also teaching composition 1&2 and business communications. The Asst. Dean was helpful.
cons: Students seemed to think, if they paid their money  they bought an A. The company usually sides with the student (client). I had one student who got a solid B but she threw a fit because it wasn't an A. She did not deserve an A in my opinion. Not as interested in students learning skills than in bringing in clients (students) and whisking them back out again.

pros: You get your own office.  Hours are flexible.  The pay is fair so are the benefits.  You work independently.  You have the satisfaction of helping a lot of people. Co-workers are friendly and helpful.  Everyone works as a team.
cons: Mgmt is horrible.  You learn the job on your own.  You have goals to meet.  If you don't meet your goals you are berated in front of your peers.

review_title: No respect for the personnel and terrible salaries.
pros: Gives those who might not otherwise have a chance at College a way in
cons: Money hungry, Top executives way overpaid, all others way underpaid. Librarians are treated like crap and expected to do everything including taking out the trash and changing light bulbs.Librarians and other Professionals are treated very badly.Open one campus after another when they say they do not have the monet for decent pay or hours and top executives paid millions way out of proportion.Wanted to respect the Institution, inthe end could not.

pros:
Some really great people do work there, but unfortunately they are not in the position of power to change many things.  The new HQ is beautiful with all the amenities one could ask for, a far cry from the office we previously were HQ in. In corporate roles, the hours are flexible - in fact most peope are not in before 9:30am, and after 5:15pm. Tuition reimbursement is a tremendous bonus for personal advancement, even if the degree isn't a Harvard MBA. Solid, robust benefits package and compensation for corporate and executive roles is at or above market value in many cases. 

Academic teams and leadership truly care about the value of the education the students get, and are essential to keeping the ship afloat.
cons:
Many people who have been there for 10+ years are treated poorly. Anyone seeking a position of power will have to compromise in order to attain that. This place was wonderful to work for prior to the current administration. 

The CEO is really not interested in the day to day anymore. What's worse, is the COO, who is waiting in the wings, may be one of the worst leaders I've seen. He could run this company straight into the ground. Taking away floating holidays and eliminating certain benefits disguised as "for the good of the employee" is not a sound management policy, regardless of who you are. While employees may be underpaid, many of them are not foolish. 

While Academics genuinely cares, they take a backseat to the Operational leadership. Because at the end of the day, its ALL about numbers. This is said point blank in meetings, with the caveat of not repeating it elsewhere. It is a for profit institution. By the very definition, they are there to make money. Numbers=money=profit. By having many unqualified students in MBA classrooms,  they make their numbers. This hurts the reputation of the school, and diminishes the hard work put forth by qualified Academians. 

The scale is misbalanced, as executives  are well whereas most employees are barely paid a living wage for what in essence is sales. 

Many departments have been overrun with unqualified, leaders who have been placed in their role for their relationship with management, rather than on proven performance.

review_title: Akron, Ohio - Campus Dean - Dr. Talil Abrhiem (Dr. T.)
pros: Although short-lived, my experience with Strayer and working closely with Dr. T has been a joy.  Working alongside Dr. T has taught me so many valuable lessons and skills, mainly, his leadership and work ethic, which is highly respected amongst students and colleagues.  It is my hope to work underneath him in the future.  As a mentor, leader, colleague and friend Dr. T. is prime example of what a leader should be and a great asset to the company.
cons: In Lleu of closing our campus I wish I worked here longer to obtain the necessary leadership skills, knowledge, and experience from Dr. T.

pros: Can't really think of anything positive.
cons: Don't expect anything more than a 1% raise, if you are one of the lucky ones.  Terrible work/life balance, though some other departments may have it better than my team does.  Requesting a day off seems like a criminal act.

pros: Benefits package is definitely good. The pay here is competetive with the industry
cons: The company is in flux trying to adjust to a new marketplace. This means a lot of uncertainty.

review_title: Frustrating to try and teach here
pros: Courses are designed and set up for adjunct faculty.
cons: I taught part time online for about eight years. Each year the academic integrity went down, down, down, while our work load increased (post videos, etc,)  and pay stayed stagnant. A lot of student cheating and low quality work with Deans and administration forcing faculty to change failing grades upward to pass students.. Starting to approach a diploma mill.

pros: none to speak of. great staff in some location. They lose all good employees due to low pay and not knowing how treat employees,
cons: Low pay, the lowest I ever seen for a Librarian with a Masters degree. No professionalism toward academics staff. The cheapest organization I ever worked for. The students are tricked into enrolling and their degree is not respected. Constant changes to management staff, most people leave as soon as they can. They recruit anyone with student aid for students. No raises for  LRCM staff. You are always during the career services job and they expect the LRCM managers to clean the boards and labs. The worse place to work ever Run away as quick as possible.

review_title: If culture, trust, and competent leadership are important to you, keep looking.
job_title: Admissions in West Valley City, UT
pros: The pay is wonderful, the benefits package is excellent, you can get your degree quickly, there is unlimited overtime.
cons: Management is poor. Expectations are unclear and change on the drop of a dime. The criteria to move up doesn't make sense. Leadership is next to never on the floor with their people. Management lacks the competencies to lead, they are simply task completers. The Management team is promoted based off politics and who will be the most likely to agree blindly to what second tier management proposes without any level of critical thinking or care for unintended consequences to the students or employee moral. When feedback is asked for by employees, you have to pull teeth to get them to tell you what you can improve on. When feed back is finally given, it does not make sense and is often the same thing you were told you are amazing at last week. There is a culture of silence- there is a strong fear of retaliation. Leadership isn't respected and has a reputation among the teams to being incompetent, doing nothing, and not listening to their teams. If you value clear communication, clear expectations, growth, leadership vs. management, positive team culture, feeling heard, and feeling valued then keep looking. If you value stroking the right egos, if you are great at staying silent and keeping your opinions to yourself, if you are great at manipulating numbers and reporting, you will advance quickly. If you want a stable well paying job where you don't need to do much of anything to advance, this is the place for you,

review_title: Depending on position, Ok if looking for something to do with your time
pros: Opportunity to take classes, only if you are full time.
cons: Training is through website video, other training is on the fly. Depending on department, opportunity for  promotions are not available. The company could be more family friendly.  Too much focus on recruitment and not enough focus on providing all the courses students may need.  Even though no classes, Saturday work required.

pros:
- Great for someone who does not mind undue pressure
-  Rhetoric focus on student success
- Excellent feeling to know you are changing a person's life
- Very good starting salary and benefits
- Food days and perks
cons:
- You must create your own network to survive
- Management changes and retracts protocol with moderate frequency
-Your conversations with students are monitored
- Pressure from upper management falls flatly on Admissions Officers 
- People are promoted on performance (meeting goals) and not management capability

pros: While working here, I met some truly fantastic people. Many of my coworkers were dedicated to helping the students and were a pleasure to work with. 90% off tuition is a great benefit, and something that most people working here take advantage of.
cons:
When I first started, I was literally thrown into the middle of everything without any basic training, including training on the school. As an Admissions Officer, I found it counterproductive to sell the school without any basic product knowledge. I use that terminology, because despite the "Admissions Officer" title that job is purely a high-pressure sales position with the students and their money from FASFA the sales.

During my tenure as an Admissions Officer, I cannot count on my hands how many different coworkers I had- and that is JUST the Admissions Officer position! The turnover is unusually high, and even the students will ask why there are always new people working in the administration office. The students are also always concerned about classes being canceled or their campus getting closed. Despite what they are being told- they have every right to be concerned. Everything is treated as a secret at Strayer, to the employees and students alike. No one knows what bad decision will be enforced next, until the changes have already been made.

Middle management (the Campus Directors) seem to be under a significant amount of pressure to "bring in the numbers", which means that every single one of them constantly micromanages everything that goes on in Admissions. And if for some reason you cannot meet their unrealistic quota (for reasons, such as, it's the week before Christmas and no one wants to talk to you about going to college) you are not only publicly chastised in front of all your colleagues, but you are told that if you keep that up you will be without a job. That is, unless you are said manager's favorite employee- nepotism runs rampant throughout this company. People are promoted due to being a favorite employee, regardless of their ability to manage or handle the responsibility of the position. For instance, incompetent workers are being promoted to Campus Director positions, even without the minimum of a college degree.

This pressure from management permeates among the lower level employees, and causes "team members" to steal sales (aka students) from each other, etc. This kind of behavior is only encouraged, since these "high performers" are put on a pedestal and then promoted even without possessing basic management skills. These favorites then get preferential treatment, for things such as salary. There is NO standard salary at Strayer- as an Admissions Officer some people earned as little as $34,000 while others earned "as much as" $45,000. For the EXACT same job, which was supposed to be not given monetary compensated for "sales".

pros: Good people to work with and good opportunities to enhance your teaching skills. Lots of tools and job aids are available.  The environment changes so have an opportunity to learn new things.
cons: Getting a fulltime faculty position is difficult.  The environment is ever changing.  If you have difficulty adjusting to change than this is not the right environment for you.

review_title: Great Environment to Work with a Great Team.
pros: Working at Strayer University gives you the opportunity to meet great individuals and learn from one of the most talented educators.  The diversity with in the student body also empowers you to learn, understand, and help others strive towards their goals.  Because I was trained by Strayer as an employee and as a student I feel confident and stronger than I was before working there.
cons:
-Lacks in-classroom class size
-Lack of career advancement

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The pay and benefits are really good.
cons: The sales environment fosters a lot of stress and negativity. The management claims to hold integrity to a high standard but if sales quotas are down (aka student enrollment), integrity and honesty go out the window. They don't care if students succeed, they just want to collect financial aid to satisfy the stock holders. It doesn't matter if a potential student doesn't even own a computer to do online coursework or can't fill out a basic admissions application without assistance. If there's doubt a potential sale didn't graduate from high school, put their enrollment up for the night and deal with it later when the "student" has already been charged thousands of dollars before dropping them.

pros: Benefits were great, and opportunities as long as the company and education industry were doing well.
cons: Lots and lots of politics.

job_title: Success Coach in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Great people
Benefits are great
Strayer apparel
Good atmosphere 
Pay is decent
Overtime possibility 
Remote option
Campus locations throughout the nation
Flexible
cons:
Unappreciative of their employees
Too much work

High call volume (calls are nonstop)
No incentives
Poor leadership
Lack of communication 
Difficult to get ahold of anyone
Not structured (No one knows what they are doing)

review_title: Team atmosphere, but overly driven by numbers
job_title: Director of Admissions in Raleigh, NC
pros: Working with dedicated staff made the job in admissions enjoyable. It was also nice to help people achieve their education goals.
cons: In admissions, there was a lot of micromanaging. Also, it became more of a numbers game then actually focusing on the quality of the student. We were often encouraged to admit people who truly weren't ready for that level of education.

review_title: Unethical Work Environment with EEOC Issues
pros: Collecting a paycheck, health & education benefits.
cons: Horrible work environment. Shady management who engage in petty, high school gossip and backbiting while smiling in your face. Extremely high turn over. Unethical university as a whole which does not take appropriate actions when reporting EEOC issues but instead, penalizes the person who reports them. I was sexually harassed and let go for not remaining calm against the person who harassed me for 4 months. Unreal.

job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Chantilly, VA
pros:
Good job for starting out.
There are a lot of great people that work there
Paid overtime 
Paid well for what the job is
cons:
Managers pick certain employees they like and are friends with and are more lenient with them. 
There tends to be favorites and nepotism 
There is not enough communications and managers tend to micromanage and refuse to delegate tasks to the leaders they have hired.

pros: Strayer is serious about providing a quality education to working adults. They set a high standard for federal compliance and hold themselves accountable. They have changed and improved their operations significantly over the last 5 years and seek to be a leader in the industry.
cons: Slow to fix departments within the corporate office which negatively impacts the rest of the organization.  Working around these departments or absorbing their work is often the only way to fix it.

review_title: Experience was one of the worst in my career
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Downers Grove, IL
pros: There are very few pros to working there unless you want to get a degree not worth much since, as faculty, we are asked to tutor, coach, and do anything creative so the student passes the class
cons: The ethics of the management are very poor and they ask you to ignore the law and be very helpful to the students, some times to the point where you are ignoring any kind of standards. The company is not in the business of educating students but in the business of manufacturing worthless degrees and getting students in debt

job_title: Adjunct Mathematics and Statistics Instructor in Downers Grove, IL
pros: Pay is higher than other schools. People are friendlier and more accepting of students with disabilities, physically and educationally!
cons: If campus does not make a lot of money they close it down and leave faculty and students stranded!!!!

job_title: Business Office Manager in Bloomington, MN
pros: Very nice facilities and equipment - they equip their offices and classrooms with very nice equipment and furniture compared to other similar schools
cons: CONSTANT management changes!  I was only there about a year and there were 3 (!) upper management changes in that time!  Each new manager had a different focus and outlook so the campus staff had to constantly change what we did on a daily basis as well

pros: This company has good framework and good policies. The do's and don't are very clear. If you apply yourself you will do well. The paid time off is excellent, all major holidays off and floating holidays too.
cons: Frequent organizational changes. It is difficult to get comfortable in your job knowing there could be a change that leaves you without a job soon. Management seems disconnected from the day to day operation and do not always treat simple processes with the urgency it requires.

job_title: Associate Campus Dean in Herndon, VA
pros: Leveraging resources with other regional leadership is a positive powerful experience.
cons:
Some decisions made by the  Regional Deans should give more attention to students.
The for profit principles contribute to students graduating with huge amounts of debt and no job placement.

review_title: Management cares about share prices not the students or employee development
pros: 90% Tuition Assistance and a stable source of income.
cons: Goal oriented, enrollment numbers matter more than the quality of service provided. No work-life balance. Management takes no responsibility of operations. Student's are pushed from person to person in hopes that they will simply "drop their problem".

pros: The majority of people I work with daily here on campus are good-hearted, kind, personable folks. That's definitely it for the pros.
cons: There is a complete lack of work to life balance. The AO's are put under constant stress, with very little compensation. The students are more often than not coming to school for reasons other than getting an education. This is a fairly depressing environment to be in on a daily basis.

review_title: Typical Diploma Mill Where Numbers Matter More Than People
pros: You get a paycheck every 2 weeks and they provide free food occasionally. Free coffee. Front desk staff are friendly and very helpful.
cons: Horrible work hours. No work/life balance. Management is unethical and dishonest, and upper management does nothing to change this. All about numbers, doesn't care about employees. Don't trust anything that comes from the mouth of the campus manager or market director at the South Charlotte campus. Looks great from the outside, but rotten inside.

review_title: I liked helping students, but it was too much of "Favorites"
pros: Discount on classes, benefits were great, campuses were across the nation.  Training was very helpful in navigating the education system.

review_title: Company is a joke, turn back now
job_title: Admissions Officer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: 90% off tuition and the classes are all online. If you prefer online classes and next to nothing in tuition then this is the job for you. However, the quality of education is seriously lacking.
cons: I worked in admissions and I had a great interview before I started the job. I actually was offered jobs with 3 other companies and turned them down because I was so excited about the possibility of working for this company. Not at all what I was lead to believe and or expected. It is a complete and total sales position.They give off the impression that you will be helping students achieve a better life. Total joke! Seriously, the only way to do well at this company is to adopt a sales mindset and throw out any possibility of really connecting with the students. It is a complete and total numbers game. They only care about the numbers so much that if you tell upper management you truly believe a student is not a good fit for this university, then they will just pass your student off to the another admissions officer and see if they can enroll the student instead. So more often than not you're cheating the students by talking them into gaining an education with our university when in fact, they're accruing several thousand in debt. They probably won't graduate because they should have attended a brick and mortar institution instead but were lead to believe that this is the best education they'll receive. LIES. The company also promises numerous opportunities for growth and advancement but advancement isn't based off of merit. It is a boys club and with very few women in upper management. Women can only be promoted if they're willing to play "the game". They also say they promote people based off of their numbers for prior quarters but coming from an admissions officer who actually did well in their position despite all the foolishness, this isn't the case either.  Anyone who is in upper management got there clearly because they were friends with someone else in upper management. You can put your hand in the pot several times but unless you're willing to play the game, you're not going to move up in this company. Not to mention the corporate office visits on numerous occasions and they give these grand speeches of how well the company is doing and that there will be more possibilities of progress/advancement with raises included. Total joke and everybody worth their salt knows it. It was as if corporate was dangling a carrot in our faces, like we were children and would believe anything they told us. Yet we asked the same questions every meeting "how long will our office be here?", "will (blank) dept be shutting down", "will there be an increase in pay anytime soon?" Never got a straight answer and most of the time we were told that they were taking our questions into consideration and that they working on it. I was with the company for one year and it was the same b/s every time. I got so fed up with it  that I finally just resigned. Not to mention more than half the managers at the company don't know how to manage people. They literally treat us like we're children, buying our lunches every so often so as to compensate for the what they are clearly lacking. Several people are hired as temps then laid off shortly thereafter without any warning and lots of people just end up quitting. Don't bother putting in a two week notice either, cause typically they won't let you finish the two weeks. It's not worth it to work there, especially if you're passionate about education. If you want to make a difference in someone's life, work for a traditional university as an advisor or something similar. Take my advice and walk the other way. It's a perfect job if: you're sales oriented and it doesn't really matter what you sell, you don't mind sucking up and being apart of clearly a "boys club",  don't mind lunches as substitutions for raises, and don't need a work life balance because you'll spend long hours meeting your numbers here, then this is the perfect job for you.

pros: My location had a great work enviroment. They offer good benefits  and excellent  vacation and holidays.Very easy work just call people and schedule interviews.

review_title: One of the most stressful job in my life. if I could give less than one star then I would do it.
pros: I was a Campus Dean and enjoyed my interactions with other Deans.  Networking and sharing our difficulties was helpful.  It was also good that sometimes we wouldnot agree with corporate and voice our discontent as an entire group.  Glad I am gone but I still keep in touch with the people  I worked with. Most of them also saw the light and have moved on too.
cons: Rules, regulations, and policies changed daily, sometimes hourly, by the Regional Leadership. Registration numbers and the pressure to increase registration meant we pressured students who were not capable to learning even developmental coursework to register.  Most all students were on financial aid so each quarter there were at least 20 students we knew were not going to succeed (Most were Special Education students with IQs in the very low 80;s.  The bottom line was after three quarters they were dismissed after taking precollege classes and owing over 20k in student loans.  I asked corporate several time about the ethics of doing this and they would shrug their shoulders and say the student had a right to fail. I would have daily tutoring sessions by highly qualified faculty, but the lack of care for the student was very difficult to live with.  Well, that and the gossip, backstabbing, and corporate personnel changes that brought new rules that often werent handed down until the campus broke the unknown rule.

pros: Easy work- easy hours, benefits
cons: Management is unprofessional, duplicitous, quick to form cliques in order to help the favored advance.  Upward mobility is nil.  Leadership at regional level and campus level is poor/unskilled/immature and conniving. Gender bias is REAL in the Southeast region: girl's club to the extreme, hive of gossip queens.  Only #'s matter here- the education offered is poor, students are set up for failure, moves a lot like a degree mill.

pros:
-Pays well compared to industry standards
-Training is paid
-At some campuses office space is provided
-Will gather sales experience
-Rewarding when you have students that are so happy when you help them reach their educational goals
cons: Unrealistic sales goal expectations, they want you to make 5 students a week and realistically you may enroll only 2-3 student on a great week. This company places so much daily pressure, ex: you could have enrolled 3 students on one day and the next day enroll no one and management will put added pressure and stress on you for not meeting your daily goal. They say "goal" and each day ask you how many students you will enroll that day. If you have no one in your pipeline, then that looks bad and if you forecast 1 or more, and don't meet your  forced personal goal then its another stressor. I see new hires walk into the door and want to scream, "RUN!!! as fast as you can and never turn back!" If you hate micro-management, this is another reason why this company isn't for you. Every few hours, I have to send senior management an update of what I did up until that point. Management is incompetent.  They only promote based on who received the most enrollments. Management talks down to you. I seen someone yelled at and was told, "If you want to leave you can leave, no one is stopping you." Management is unprofessional! In order to take vacation, you must give an 30 day notice but they can and will change your schedule with less than a 24 hour notice and make it mandatory for you to come in. Moral is low. Attrition rate is high. Training is limited. This a company that cares only about money, nothing about their employees or its students. Its all about the dollar sign. Its sicking how they pretend to want to help students, and the next minute call them idiots and incompetent. Management will not listen to you. I wish I would have had someone tell me this before I started.

pros: You can go to school for 90% free. I am required to write more since this is a 20 word minimum, however there is nothing else to say that is positive.
cons: The focus is on getting students registered the "same day" without any regard to what is best for the student. It is a daily constant pressure to produce "numbers" (students), and you leave work so stressed out because you are fearful that you will lose your job if you don't register students every day. Admissions should be about showcasing the school to the prospective student so they can make the decision that works best for them, however if you have an appointment that leaves without registering, you are taken into a meeting to discuss why you did not register that appointment and what you did wrong. The work/life balance is attrocious for employees, and you are constantly told that you need to continue to keep forging ahead and working 6 days a week even when there are massive layoffs and people are losing their jobs all over the University. You work very long hours, and there is no regard to your personal life and having any kind of life outside of this company. The bottom line is, is that if you want a job with longevity and stability, do not even think of applying. There is no one that works at any of the campuses that has been there more than 2-3 years because they are constantly running employees into the ground, and are laying off or firing workers who do not produce the numbers they want. If you were to go to a traditional University, ask around, majority of the staff has been there for years, so that should tell you something when a "University" cannot keep employees. If you are a student or a potential employee, it is not worth the paycheck. Run, run, run and, if you can, do a Forrest Gump run.

job_title: Student Account Representative in Chesapeake, VA
pros: Benefits were great and kicked in after a month of full time employment. Health insurance was very inexpensive and vision was outstanding!  Paid time off accrued very quickly as opposed to waiting a year for enough available time.  There were regular holidays, floating holidays, sick, and personal time.  Training was provided in Herndon, VA at the corporate office and it was a great experience.
cons:
I only lasted long enough to keep the job on my resume. I enjoy my line of work and didn't want a short employment stint to hurt me.  The campus did not have a comfortable open door atmosphere where I felt like I could receive help and information when I needed it.  Managers would get frustrated and sometimes loud with students, slam doors closed, slam phones down (on students and other staff!), or stomp away from students in anger.  Other coworkers would hit the ignore buttons on their phones constantly.  You could hear when one person would do it... and then magically the next phone would ring because no one else wanted to answer.  This happened multiple times a day, multiple times a week.  With these attitudes, students became angry.  There was no team environment and it made it very miserable to work there.  

Work/life balance was stressful due to inconsistent evening & weekend rotations with coworkers. I expected to have to work evenings and weekends because I've had experience in this line of work, but I seriously feel that I had less of a life at home during my employment with this company.   

The company seems great, so maybe future employees would have a better experience in a different campus environment than the one I was in.  I went home in tears several times and woke up dreading to go into work.  My negative experience really was more about the daily environment and the campus staff than the company itself.  

Managers spent several TWO hour lunches together gossiping or being loud in the break area.  If I ever ran into questions that needed immediate answers, I felt hesitant to interrupt those "lunches" in fear of being looked at with the side eye or spoken to with an attitude.
